instruction: Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 0.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 1.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 2.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 5.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 7.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 13.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 42.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that exits with code 100.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that prints exactly 'Hello, World!\n'.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that prints exactly 'OK\n'.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that prints exactly 'NASM\n'.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that prints exactly '42\n'.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that prints exactly 'done\n'.
Write a NASM x86-64 Linux program that prints exactly 'pass\n'.
Compute 7 * 8 and exit with that value as status code.
Compute 20 + 22 and exit with that value as status code.
Compute 100 - 13 and exit with that value as status code.
Compute 6 * 7 and exit with that value as status code.
Compute 50 / 2 using idiv and exit with that value as status code.
Compute max(30, 17) using cmp/cmov and exit with that value as status code.
Compute 10 + 20 - 5 and exit with that value as status code.
Compute 3 * 9 and exit with that value as status code.
Sum numbers from 1 to 5 using a loop and exit with the result as status code.
Sum numbers from 1 to 10 using a loop and exit with the result as status code.
Sum numbers from 1 to 20 using a loop and exit with the result as status code.
Sum even numbers from 2 to 10 (2+4+6+8+10=30) using a loop and exit with the result as status code.
Loop 7 times, adding 3 each iteration starting from 0, and exit with the final value (21) as status code.
Compute the 10th Fibonacci number F(10)=55 (1-indexed: F(1)=1, F(2)=1) using a loop and exit with that value as status code.
